title: How to Heal a Sore Tongue

steps.title: Use a salt water mouth rinse.
steps.content: Use a salt water mouth rinse. A warm rinse with salt water will clean your tongue and may help relieve the pain of a sore tongue. [2] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. You can rinse every couple of hours until your pain and discomfort ease. [3] X Research source Add one tablespoon of salt to a glass of warm water and stir to dissolve. Swish a mouthful around 30 seconds, concentrating on the sore area of the tongue. Spit out the water when you're done. [4] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020.

steps.title: Rinse a bitten tongue with cold water.
steps.content: Rinse a bitten tongue with cold water. If you’ve bitten your tongue, rinse it off with cold water. This can remove any dirt, food, blood, or debris from the area and help prevent an infection. If you have bitten all the way through your tongue, make sure to get to your doctor as soon as possible. Once you’ve rinsed the tongue with cold water, you can try sucking on some ice to help with swelling and pain.

steps.title: Suck on an ice cube or ice pop.
steps.content: Suck on an ice cube or ice pop. Suck on an ice cube or ice pop if you have pain and/or burning sensation on your tongue. The cold will help to numb any feelings of pain, reduce swelling, and make your tongue feel more comfortable. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Sucking on an ice cube can be especially soothing if you’ve bitten or burned your tongue. The melting liquid will also help you stay hydrated and prevent your tongue from drying out, which can make pain from a bitten or burnt tongue worse.

steps.title: Drop a bit of honey on your tongue.
steps.content: Drop a bit of honey on your tongue. Honey helps to keep wounds moist, and it has natural antibacterial properties. Apply the honey directly or mix it in with lukewarm tea. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can also apply honey to a sterilized wound dressing material rather than applying it directly. [7] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source

steps.title: Place a cool chamomile tea bag on your tongue.
steps.content: Place a cool chamomile tea bag on your tongue. Chamomile has natural anti-inflammatory and antioxidant qualities. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Steep a chamomile tea bag, then let it cool off or put it in the refrigerator. Then, place the bag on your tongue for up to 20 minutes.

steps.title: Avoid consuming anything that could aggravate a sore tongue.
steps.content: Avoid consuming anything that could aggravate a sore tongue. When suffering from a sore tongue, it's a good idea to avoid consuming anything that may make the pain worse, such as spicy or acidic foods or tobacco. Although this won't speed up the healing process, it will likely make you more comfortable. [9] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. Eat soft, soothing and even cooling foods that won't aggravate your tongue as you eat, such as smoothies, porridge and soft fruits like bananas. Yogurt and ice cream are also good options because they are cooling and soothing. Acidic foods and beverages, such as tomatoes, orange juice, soft drinks, and coffee can make your pain worse. Also avoid cinnamon and mint, which can increase your discomfort. Try toothpaste that is formulated for sensitive teeth or something without mint or cinnamon. Don’t smoke cigarettes or chew tobacco, which can exacerbate your discomfort.

steps.title: Drink more fluids.
steps.content: Drink more fluids. Make sure that you’re staying hydrated throughout the day. This may help ease the feeling of a dry mouth. [10] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source It also can help soothe a burnt tongue. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source . Drink plenty of cool water or juices to keep your mouth moist. Try to avoid hot beverages like coffee or tea so that they don’t worsen the burning or painful sensations on your tongue. Avoid caffeine or alcohol, which can irritate your tongue.

steps.title: Get tests and a diagnosis.
steps.content: Get tests and a diagnosis. If you’re experiencing a sore tongue or the symptoms of burning tongue syndrome, your doctor may order tests to determine the cause of your pain. Tests often can’t determine the cause of a sore tongue, but your doctor will help develop the best treatment plan for you. Your doctor may use different diagnostic tools to determine the cause of your sore tongue. These include blood tests, oral cultures, a biopsy, allergy tests, and stomach acid tests. They may also give you a psychological questionnaire to rule out whether your sore tongue is related to anxiety, depression, or stress. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your doctor may also tell you to discontinue certain medications to rule them out as a cause of your sore tongue. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take medication for your sore tongue.
steps.content: Take medication for your sore tongue. Depending on the outcome of your tests, your doctor may prescribe medication to help alleviate the condition causing your sore tongue. If the tests can’t find a cause, your doctor may also prescribe medication or home treatments to relieve the pain and discomfort. Three medications commonly prescribed for a sore tongue are amitriptyline, amisulpride, and olanzapine. These drugs work by blocking the action of gamma-butyric acid, which may be responsible for the pain or burning sensation in the tongue. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Your doctor may also advise that you take an over the counter pain reliever to help relieve the discomfort of a sore tongue, especially if you are having trouble sleeping. [15] X Research source Popular over-the-counter painkillers include acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and aspirin. Follow your doctor’s orders for taking pain relievers or the instructions on the packaging. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Use throat lozenges or sprays.
steps.content: Use throat lozenges or sprays. Throat lozenges or sprays that contain mild analgesics can help soothe a sore tongue. [17] X Research source You can purchase throat lozenges and sprays at any drug store or their online sites. Use throat lozenges or sprays every two to three hours, or according to the package or your doctor’s directions. [18] X Research source Make sure to suck on the throat lozenge until it has completely dissolved. Don't try to chew it or swallow it whole, which may numb your throat and make it difficult to swallow. Reader Poll: We asked 126 wikiHow readers and 63% of them said that they like to use lozenges to relieve mouth and throat pain . [Take Poll]

steps.title: Apply capsaicin cream to soothe the tongue.
steps.content: Apply capsaicin cream to soothe the tongue. Capsaicin cream is a topical analgesic that can help relieve pain. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can apply capsaicin cream to your tongue three or four times a day. [20] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The cream will initially increase the pain sensations on the tongue, but these will subside quickly. [21] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Be aware that the prolonged use of capsaicin cream can damage fibers in the tongue tissue, leading to a permanent loss of sensation. [22] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Use an antiseptic mouthwash.
steps.content: Use an antiseptic mouthwash. Use an antiseptic mouthwash such as benzydamine or chlorhexidine to treat infections of your tongue or mouth. They may also help relieve pain and swelling on the tongue. [23] X Research source Benzydamine relieves pain by blocking prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are chemicals that are produced when there is pain from inflammation. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Pour 15 ml of benzydamine into a cup and then swish it around your mouth for 15 to 20 seconds before spitting it out. If the benzydamine is too strong, dilute it in water at a 1-to-1 ratio. [25] X Research source

steps.title: See your doctor.
steps.content: See your doctor. If you are experiencing a sore tongue and home remedies don’t help, consult your doctor. They will help identify the cause of your pain and the right kind of treatment for you. A sore tongue can have many causes including fungal, viral, or bacterial infections of the mouth, nutritional deficiencies, ill-fitting dentures, teeth grinding or over brushing your tongue, allergies, stress, or anxiety. [26] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source A sore tongue may also be the result of burning mouth syndrome. [27] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You may not notice any physical changes to your tongue or mouth with a medical condition. Or, you may experience common signs of irritation or infection, such as the white plaque coating the tongue in oral thrush, bumps, ulcers, or a burning sensation. [28] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source
